description: The Optional Binding Mandatory Curtailment (OBMC) program exempts customers from rotating outages in exchange for reducing their entire circuit's load by up to 15% during every rotating outage. This program is designed to maintain grid stability during Stage 3 emergencies when CAISO declares rotating outages. Participants must develop and submit an OBMC Plan acceptable to SCE prior to participation. Unlike other demand response programs, OBMC provides no monetary incentive - the sole benefit is exemption from rotating outages, with significant penalties ($6.00/kWh) for non-performance.

service_territories: SCE service territory in Southern California

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Eligible customers are those who can independently or in aggregate reduce their entire circuit's load by up to 15%, in increments of 5%, during every rotating outage. Large customers with demand of 300 kW or more receive telephone notification of rotating outages. No specific minimum capacity requirement stated for OBMC enrollment.

resource_types: behind-the-meter battery storage (eligibility not explicitly confirmed)
eligibility.additional_notes: Customers must be on a single distribution circuit. Program is available to bundled service or Direct Access customers with interval billing meters. When applicable, SCE may contact other businesses on the circuit to invite them to participate to achieve the required load reduction in aggregate. CCA (Community Choice Aggregation) customer eligibility is not explicitly specified in available documentation.

notification.notification_details: Rotating outages are called by CAISO during Stage 3 emergencies (EEA 3). SCE notifies large customers (300 kW or more demand) by telephone and/or other means. An ISO order for curtailment may require shut-off of power in 10 minutes or less. For all other customers, warnings are given by mass media. OBMC participants must be prepared to reduce load within 30 minutes of notification by SCE.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Excess energy charges of $6.00/kWh apply if the customer (or group of customers on a circuit) fails to achieve the required circuit load reduction of up to 15% during a rotating outage. This penalty applies to the amount of energy consumption that exceeds the customer's baseline during the event.

payment_structure.payment_details: There are no monetary incentives for participating in OBMC. The sole benefit is exemption from total load reductions during rotating outages. However, participating customers are subject to significant penalties for non-performance.

seasons.notes: Season runs from 12:00 a.m. June 1 through 12:00 a.m. October 1
All other periods outside of Summer season

call_windows.notes: Rotating outages can be called at any time during a CAISO Stage 3 Emergency (EEA 3). Events typically occur during periods of extreme heat and high electricity demand. Historical data shows events have occurred during afternoon and evening hours during heat waves, but there is no fixed call window - events are triggered by grid emergency conditions.

event_parameters.event_trigger_details: Events are triggered by CAISO declaring a Stage 3 Emergency (EEA 3), which occurs when demand outpaces available supply and the ISO is unable to meet minimum contingency reserve requirements. Rotating outages typically last approximately one hour. Participants must reduce load by up to 15% on their entire circuit during every rotating outage for the entire period of the outage.
event_parameters.load_reduction_requirements: Circuit load must be reduced by up to 15%, available in increments of 5% (i.e., 5%, 10%, or 15%). Performance is measured against a 10-day baseline with an optional 'Day-Of' adjustment.
event_parameters.response_requirements: Customers must drop their entire contracted load reduction within 30 minutes of notification by SCE, and maintain the load reduction until 90 minutes after the notification time, unless SCE notifies them they can restore power earlier.

nomination_bidding.nomination_details: Customers electing to participate must develop and submit a workable OBMC Plan and obtain SCE approval of the OBMC Plan prior to participation. The plan must detail how the entire circuit's load will be reduced by up to 15 percent during each rotating outage. Circuit load information must be provided. SCE may contact other businesses on the circuit to invite them to participate if needed to achieve the required reduction.

baseline_methodology.baseline_calculation: Performance is measured based on a 10-day baseline (10-in-10 methodology), which excludes OBMC, CPP, or other DR program event days from the baseline calculation.

day_of_adjustment.method: The 'Day-Of' adjustment is calculated as a ratio of (a) the average load of the first three hours of the four hours before the event to (b) the average load of the same hours from the last 10 weekdays.

baseline_methodology.metering_requirements: Interval billing meters required. Approved hourly metering may be required for accurate baseline and performance measurement.

special_attributes: No monetary incentives - only rotating outage exemption
Mandatory participation in every rotating outage
Binding commitment with penalties for non-performance
Coordination required among multiple customers on same circuit when applicable

program_evolution.change_description: Program was likely established following the 2000-2001 California energy crisis when rotating outages became a critical grid management tool. Fact sheet copyright shows 2010, indicating program was active by that time.
CPUC adopted 10-in-10 baseline with day-of adjustment for demand response programs including OBMC, replacing earlier 3-in-10 baseline methodology.

program_history.notes: Program history details, launch year, and enrollment statistics are not publicly available in accessible documentation. The program is designed for infrequent but critical grid emergencies.

historical_events.notes: CAISO declared Stage 3 Emergency during extreme heat wave. First rotating outages in California since 2001. OBMC participants would have been required to perform.
Second consecutive day of Stage 3 Emergency and rotating outages during August 2020 heat wave.

CAISO declared EEA 3 when electricity demand reached all-time high of 51,426 MW. However, successful conservation efforts prevented rotating outages from being implemented. OBMC participants would have been on standby.

recent_grid_reliability_context.notes: Between 2020-2024, CAISO only implemented rotating outages during August 14-15, 2020 during an extreme heat wave. A Stage 3 Emergency was declared September 6, 2022, but rotating outages were avoided through successful conservation efforts. No Stage 3 emergencies with rotating outages occurred in 2023 or 2024. This indicates OBMC is an infrequent but critical backstop program for extreme grid emergency situations.

data_sources.source_name: SCE Schedule OBMC Tariff (PDF - not accessible)
CAISO Rotating Power Outages Fact Sheet
CPUC Decision on Demand Response Baseline Methodology

integration_metadata.notes: OBMC is not suitable for battery optimization systems because: (1) Events are extremely rare (only 2 days in past 4+ years), (2) Notice can be as little as 10 minutes, making automated response challenging, (3) There is no monetary compensation - only penalty avoidance, (4) Program requires circuit-wide coordination and SCE approval of plans, (5) Penalties are severe ($6/kWh) for non-performance. The program is a binding commitment for grid emergencies rather than an economic optimization opportunity. Battery systems participating would need to be sized and committed to respond to every rotating outage on their circuit.

data_quality_assessment.verification_method: Multiple authoritative sources cross-referenced including SCE official program documentation, CPUC regulatory documents, and CAISO emergency procedures. All payment rates, penalties, and program rules verified from official utility sources. Historical event data verified from CAISO announcements and regulatory records.
data_quality_assessment.researcher_notes: This research adhered strictly to the data integrity requirements. NO DATA WAS INVENTED. All values are from verified sources or explicitly marked as 'not available' or 'not specified'. The OBMC program is fundamentally different from typical demand response programs - it provides NO monetary incentive, only exemption from rotating outages in exchange for a binding commitment to curtail during grid emergencies. The severe penalties ($6/kWh) and rare event frequency make this unsuitable for battery revenue optimization. This is a reliability/insurance program, not an economic program. The tariff PDF could not be parsed, so some technical details may exist in that document that are not captured here. Program contact: SCE Demand Response Help Desk at 1-866-334-7827.
